    Design, Synthesis, and Biological Evaluation of Novel Allosteric Protein Disulfide Isomerase Inhibitors

    • Suhui Yang

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Protein disulfide isomerase (PDI) is responsible for nascent protein folding in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and is critical for glioblastoma survival. To improve the potency of lead PDI inhibitor BAP2 ((E)-3-(3-(4-hydroxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile), we designed and synthesized 67 analogues. We determined that PDI inhibition relied on the A ring hydroxyl group of the chalcone scaffold and cLogP increase in the sulfonamide chain improved potency. Docking studies revealed that BAP2 and analogues bind to His256 in the b′ domain of PDI, and mutation of His256 to Ala abolishes BAP2 analogue activity. BAP2 and optimized analogue 59 have modest thiol reactivity; however, we propose that PDI inhibition by BAP2 analogues depends on the b′ domain. Importantly, analogues inhibit glioblastoma cell growth, induce ER stress, increase expression of G2M checkpoint proteins, and reduce expression of DNA repair proteins. Cumulatively, our results support inhibition of PDI as a novel strategy to treat glioblastoma.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most aggressive primary brain tumor in adults. Standard treatment for GBM consists of surgical resection followed by radiotherapy and chemotherapy with the DNA-alkylating agent temozolomide.(1) These treatments are effective at shrinking tumors initially, but they are not curative and the cancer ultimately recurs in almost all patients due to drug resistance and tumor heterogeneity.(2,3) To overcome these limitations, research into new therapies with novel mechanisms and innovative combination modalities is needed.(3−5) Unfortunately, most trials have demonstrated only modest increases in progression-free survival and no improvements in overall survival.(3,4) Therefore, there still exists an urgent unmet medical need for more effective therapies for GBM.
    Cancer cells require increased protein synthesis and respond to endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress by activating the unfolded protein response (UPR) which is mediated by ER chaperones.(6−8) ER chaperones, such as protein disulfide isomerase (PDI), have emerged as interesting targets for cancer research. PDI is an oxidoreductase chaperone, located in the ER, that assists protein folding by catalyzing disulfide-bond formation (oxidation), breakage (reduction), and rearrangement (isomerization).(9,10) PDI is composed of four thioredoxin-like domains (a, a′, b, and b′), a linker between the a′ and b′ domains (x), and a C terminal acidic tail. Both the a and a′ domains contain structurally similar active sites, including a CGHC motif, and are responsible for the oxidoreductase activity.(11) The b′ domain possesses a large hydrophobic pocket for substrate binding and recognition. The C-terminal domain functions in chaperone activity.(12) All these domains are attached in a U-shaped structure that is open in the oxidized state and closed in the reduced state. In addition to the vital roles in protein folding, PDI is overexpressed in a variety of cancers but more significantly in GBM.(9) Furthermore, upregulation of PDI is associated with acquired temozolomide resistance in GBM, and inhibition of PDI enhances temozolomide-mediated cell death through apoptosis via the ER stress response pathway.(13) Selective PDI inhibitors can sensitize several cancer cell lines to chemotherapeutic agents such as etoposide, fenretinide, and velcade.(14,15) PDI inhibition induces acute ER stress in multiple myeloma cells accompanied by apoptosis-inducing calcium release.(16) In addition, PDI is strongly expressed in invasive glioma cells, in both xenografts and at the invasive front of human GBMs, and PDI inhibition leads to reduced glioma cell migration and invasion by interfering with the integrin outside-in signaling pathway.(17,18) All these findings suggest that PDI is an important target for cancer therapy, especially for brain cancers, thus emphasizing the need for the development of novel and potent PDI inhibitors.
    Recently, we identified the PDI inhibitor BAP2, a benzylidene acetophenone, with an IC50 value of 930 ± 90 nM, via a combination of high-throughput screening and experimental analysis (unpublished) (Figure 1). BAP2 shows in vitro and in vivo antiproliferative activities in human brain cancer models as a single agent. A simple chalcone is a 1,3-diaryl-2-propen-1-one in which the two aromatic rings are connected by a three-carbon α,β unsaturated carbonyl bridge. Chalcone is considered a valuable scaffold due to its simple chemistry, ease of synthesis, and wide biological activity, including antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, and antitumor properties.(19) Several chalcones, such as metochalcone, sofalcone,(20,21) PD-156707, licochalcone A, and elafibranor, have been marketed or clinically tested for various diseases, are well-tolerated and nontoxic to humans, and they have reasonable pharmacokinetic properties (Figure 1).(22) Herein, we report the synthesis of 67 BAP2 derivatives, provide a structure–activity relationship (SAR) analysis, and present an evaluation of PDI inhibitory activity and cytotoxicity against brain cancer cells. The most potent BAP2 analogue inhibited GBM migration and cell growth, lowered MMP9 expression, and blocked MMP2 secretion. Furthermore, extensive transcriptomic and proteomic analysis of analogue treatment in a brain cancer cell line demonstrated that BAP2 and analogues induced ER stress, increased expression of G2M checkpoint proteins, and reduced expression of ribosomal and DNA replication proteins. While BAP2 and 59 have some thiol reactivity, we provide evidence that PDI inhibition by BAP2 analogues is dependent on allosteric binding in the b′ domain.

    Results

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis of BAP2 Derivatives and Their Structure–Activity Relationship

    To investigate the structural aspects of the lead BAP2 for ability to inhibit PDI reductase activity, a series of derivatives were designed and synthesized. The most commonly used method for the preparation of chalcones is the base-catalyzed Claisen–Schmidt condensation reaction between a methyl ketone and an aldehyde in the presence of sodium hydroxide (NaOH),(23,24) potassium hydroxide (KOH),(25) or lithium hydroxide (LiOH·H2O).(26) However, the base-mediated reactions sometimes require longer reaction times (several days), give low chemical yields, and have a high probability of side reactions such as the Cannizzaro reaction of an aldehyde, aldol condensation, or the Michael addition reaction.(27) On the other hand, the acid-catalyzed method involves the use of aluminum trichloride (AlCl3)(28) or dry HCl,(29) and recently boron trifluoride etherate (BF3·Et2O) has been used as a condensing agent.(30,31) This new BF3·Et2O-assisted method is advantageous over existing methods because it produces higher yields, requires shorter reaction times, and has minimal side reactions.(30,32,33) Therefore, we applied the BF3·Et2O method for the synthesis of most BAP2 derivatives in this study.
    Several 4-substituted acetophenones (3a–n) and benzaldehydes (4a,b) were prepared via typical methylation (3a),(34) nucleophilic substitution reactions with amines (3b–i, 4b), activation of acid with thionyl chloride, and the subsequent substitution reaction with nucleophiles (3j–m), hydroxylation at an aliphatic carbon of 3′-bromo-4′-methyl acetophenone (3n), and esterification of 3-carboxybenzaldehyde (4a) (Scheme 1). With the acetophenones (3) and benzaldehydes (4), most BAP2 derivatives were prepared by a modified procedure of the BF3·Et2O-assisted Claisen–Schmidt reaction (Scheme 2).(30) Some BAP2 derivatives were synthesized by applying the base-catalyzed condensation reaction (8, 9, 39),(23) and pyrazine-containing derivatives were obtained in the presence of diethylamine in pyridine at 80–120 °C (29 and 56). Microwave-assisted one-pot reaction of a Sonogashira coupling of an aryl halide with an aryl alcohol, and the subsequent base-catalyzed isomerization were carried out to provide the boronate-containing chalcone 71,(35) and further oxidative cleavage of the boronate afforded the boronic acid chalcone 72.(36) Another boronic acid chalcone 31 was prepared by Miyaura borylation of aryl halide 10 and subsequent oxidative cleavage. Microwave-assisted Suzuki coupling of aryl halide 67 afforded chalcones 68 and 69. In addition, methylation of compounds 5 and 25, demethylation of 8, esterification of 37, and base-promoted hydrolysis of 53 afforded corresponding BAP2 derivatives 7, 27, 6, 46, and 45, respectively.
    A total of 68 synthetic chalcones were prepared and tested for the inhibitory effect against PDI using the PDI reductase assay.(37,38) Their structure–activity relationship (SAR) was analyzed by categorizing the derivatives into three clusters based on the substituent of ring B. In the first series of analogues (Table 1), we maintained the nitrile group of the lead BAP2 at R2 and made modifications at R1. Replacement of the hydroxyl group (6, IC50 of 0.85 μM) with bromine (10) led to a 2-fold decrease in the inhibition of PDI activity. Activity dropped substantially upon replacement of the hydroxyl group (5, IC50 of 1.87 μM and 6) with a methoxy group (7 and 8), amine (9), or heterocycle (11, 12), and upon the introduction of a pyrazine moiety to replace the phenyl ring (29). Similarly, the compounds containing at least one hydroxyl group retained activity or showed stronger activity depending on the additional substituent (21–24, 32–36, IC50 range of 0.21–2.37 μM) regardless of the position of the nitrile at meta or para of R2. However, introduction of a methoxy group (25, 26) seemed to be unfavorable for activity even with the hydroxyl group maintained (IC50 of 10.9 and 2.72 μM, respectively). Analogue activity decreased with dimethoxy groups (27) or dihalogen atoms (28) in place of the hydroxyl group, indicating the importance of the hydroxyl group for potency. Interestingly, several BAP2 analogues lacking a hydroxyl group retained or even improved PDI inhibitory activity (13–20). These compounds contain a sulfonamide moiety in place of the hydroxyl group and increase in hydrophobic character with increasing alkyl chain. As hydrophobicity increased, the PDI inhibitory activity of the analogues improved (Supporting Information, Figure S1), and the derivatives with 3 < cLogP < 5 were quite potent, with IC50 values of 0.82–1.23 μM (15, 16, 19, 20). On the other hand, another type of sulfonamide-containing chalcone derivative (e.g., 30, IC50 of 8.51 μM) was not as potent as 20 (IC50 of 1.11 μM) although they both have a bulky hydrophobic moiety, suggesting that an electron withdrawing group such as −SO2NHR prepared the olefin for nucleophilic attack by the thiol in the active site. Potentially, the hydrophobic region would interact with a pocket near the active site to stabilize binding. These findings suggest that both active site and hydrophobic interactions play important roles in the activity of this series.
    Table 1. PDI Inhibitory Activity of the Synthesized BAP2 Derivatives 5–36a
    compdscaffoldXR1R2IC50 (μM)b
    6 (BAP2)AC4-OH3-CN0.85 ± 0.14
    5AC3-OH3-CN1.87 ± 0.58
    7AC3-OMe3-CN8.13 ± 1.53
    8AC4-OMe3-CN>500
    9AC4-NH23-CN>500
    10AC4-Br3-CN1.66 ± 0.42
    11AC4-morpholine3-CN>500
    12AC4-piperidine3-CN>500
    13AC4-SO2NH23-CN6.64 ± 0.11
    14AC4-SO2NMe23-CN6.23 ± 0.67
    15AC4-SO2NEt23-CN1.23 ± 0.06
    16AC4-SO2NPr23-CN0.82 ± 0.34
    17AC4-SO2NBu23-CN1.34 ± 0.19
    18AC4-SO2NPe23-CN0.16 ± 0.06
    19AC4-SO2NHCPh3-CN1.05 ± 0.76
    20AC4-SO2NHPh3-CN1.11 ± 0.14
    21AC2-OH, 4-F3-CN2.37 ± 1.22
    22AC3-OH, 4-F3-CN1.15 ± 0.08
    23AC3-F, 4-OH3-CN1.14 ± 0.17
    24AC3-CF3, 4-OH3-CN2.00 ± 0.37
    25AC3-OH, 4-OMe3-CN10.93 ± 0.73
    26AC3-OMe, 4-OH3-CN2.72 ± 0.74
    27AC3,4-OMe3-CN>100
    28AC3-F, 4-Cl3-CN>500
    29ANH3-CN>500
    30B N-methyl-4-nitrobenzenesulfonamide3-CN8.51 ± 3.51
    31B B(OH)23-CN0.83 ± 0.38
    32AC4-OH4-CN0.74 ± 0.09
    33AC2-OH, 4-F4-CN1.80 ± 0.60
    34AC3-OH, 4-F4-CN1.83 ± 0.49
    35AC3-F, 4-OH4-CN0.21 ± 0.08
    36AC3-CF3, 4-OH4-CN1.11 ± 0.33
    a

    Inhibition of PDI was assessed by PDI reductase assay.

    b

    IC50 values are indicated as the mean ± SD (standard error) of at least three independent experiments.

    Next, we investigated PDI inhibitory activity of the derivatives containing a carboxylic acid or carboxymethyl ester in place of the nitrile group at the meta position of R2 (Table 2). The introduction of carboxylic acid at R2 (37–45) generally reduced potency regardless of the presence of a hydroxyl group at R1. However, a carboxymethyl ester (46, 47, 49) increased potency with an IC50 range of 0.12–0.49 μM compared to compounds containing a nitrile group (5, 6, 24, IC50 range of 0.85–2.0 μM), and we obtained the most potent analogue 46 with a carboxymethyl ester (IC50 = 120 ± 10 nM) at R2. These results indicate that the carboxymethyl ester facilitates stronger binding affinity for PDI than chalcones containing other electron-withdrawing groups such as a nitrile group or carboxylic acid. Intriguingly, the activity was lost when the carboxymethyl ester at R2 was added to the sulfonamide-containing chalcones (51–53), suggesting that the chalcones with a hydroxyl group or a sulfonamide moiety at R1 may have different binding interactions.
    Table 2. PDI Inhibitory Activity of the Synthesized BAP2 Derivatives 37–53a
    compdscaffoldXR1R2IC50 (μM)b
    6 (BAP2)AC4-OH3-CN0.85 ± 0.14
    37AC3-OH3-COOH10.19 ± 1.41
    38AC4-NO23-COOH40 < IC50 < 500
    39AC4-NH23-COOH>100
    40AC4-morpholine3-COOH>100
    41AC4-piperidine3-COOH40 < IC50 < 500
    42AC3-OH, 4-OMe3-COOH>100
    43AC3-F, 4-OH3-COOH9.10 ± 2.10
    44AC3-CF3, 4-OH3-COOH4.09 ± 1.31
    45B N-methyl-4-nitrobenzenesulfonamide3-COOH4.00 ± 0.60
    46AC3-OH3-COOMe0.12 ± 0.01
    47AC4-OH3-COOMe0.40 ± 0.16
    48AC3-OH, 4-OMe3-COOMe47.8 ± 11.0
    49AC3-CF3, 4-OH3-COOMe0.49 ± 0.13
    50AC3-Br, 4-CH2OH3-COOMe0.13 ± 0.03
    51AC4-SO2NPr23-COOMe>100
    52AC4-SO2NBu23-COOMe>100
    53B N-methyl-4-nitrobenzenesulfonamide3-COOMe>100
    a

    Inhibition of PDI was assessed by PDI reductase assay.

    b

    IC50 values are indicated as the mean ± SD (standard error) of at least three independent experiments.

    We also examined the potency of BAP2 derivatives containing different functional groups such as trifluoromethyl, hydroxy, methoxy, bromo, boronate, or boronic acid moieties at R2 (Table 3). Replacing the nitrile in BAP2 (6) and 32 with a trifluoromethyl group reduced the potency about 2–4-fold (55, 57), suggesting the electron-withdrawing properties at R2 are not driving PDI inhibition. But interestingly, replacement with a heterocycle increased analogue activity with IC50 values of 0.21–0.35 μM (68–70). In a series of carboxamide-, sulfonamide-, or carboxylate-containing analogues (60–65), the compounds with a hydroxyl group at R2 afforded PDI inhibition with an IC50 range of 1.7–11 μM (60–62), but the potency was abolished upon replacement with a methoxy group (63–65), suggesting that the analogues with a hydrophobic moiety at R1 may require the hydroxyl anchor at R2 to position them for hydrophobic interactions around the binding pocket. In addition, the analogues containing −SO2NHR at R1 and hydroxyl group at R2 (58, 59) tolerated the activity compared to the ones containing nitrile group at R2 (15, 16).
    Table 3. PDI Inhibitory Activity of the Synthesized BAP2 Derivatives 54–72a
    a

    Inhibition of PDI was assessed by PDI reductase assay.

    b

    IC50 values are indicated as the mean ± SD (standard error) of at least three independent experiments.

    In addition, 17 analogues were obtained from the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Therapeutics Development Program and tested in the PDI reductase assay, but most of these analogues were inactive (Supporting Information, Table S1). Compounds containing the 6′-OH to stabilize the carbonyl were inactive in the PDI reductase assay (NC587, NC588, and NC589).
    The SAR of all derivatives are summarized in Figure 2, and the results suggest two different series of active chalcone derivatives. The first series contains a hydroxyl group at meta or para position of ring A, and the potency of compounds decreases based on the functional group on ring B as follows: COOMe ≈ Br, pyridine, benzimidazole > CN > CF3 ≫ COOH. The second series contains a sulfonamide moiety or aromatic ring with linkers such as carboxamide, carboxylate, or sulfonamide at para position on ring A, and the potency of compounds decreased based on the functional group of ring B as follows: CN ≈ OH > OMe ≈ COOMe.

    BAP2 Analogues Selectively Reduce Brain Cancer Cell Viability

    We selected 23 BAP2 analogues with IC50 values lower than 1.5 μM against PDI and tested for cytotoxicity in a panel of brain cancer cell lines (U87MG, A172, and NU04) (Table 4). Compound 19 was not soluble in DMSO and therefore not considered further in this study. The BAP2 analogues were moderately cytotoxic to U87MG cells, with IC50 values from 10 to 30 μM for most of the analogues. In general, the NU04 cells were more sensitive than the U87MG cells to treatment. Compounds more potent than BAP2 (6) in both A172 and NU04 cells included 18, 59, 68, 69, and 70. Among the compounds, 18 was the most potent in both U87MG and A172 cells (IC50 = 5.6 ± 2.1 and 9.0 ± 3.4 μM, respectively). Compound 69 was the most potent in the NU04 cell line, with an IC50 value of 3.8 ± 0.1 μM. These chalcone derivatives also inhibited PDI activity more potently compared to PACMA31,(37) a previously reported PDI inhibitor (Figure 3A,B). Treatment with BAP2 caused lipid vesicles to form around the nucleus of the cell after 48 h (Supporting Information, Figure S2), whereas inactive analogue 8 did not visibly affect cell morphology. Furthermore, 46 created a ring of debris around the cell akin to necroptotic cell death, while 59 exhibited vesicle formation and membrane blebbing. Next, we investigated the effect of five BAP2 derivatives on GBM cell proliferation (Figure 3C). All compounds generally showed a dose-dependent inhibition of colony formation in U87MG cells. BAP2 was less potent in the colony formation assay than in the MTT assay as it inhibited less than 40% of cell proliferation at 10 μM, whereas the IC50 value of BAP2 in U87MG cells was 10.7 ± 1.8 μM (Table 4). Interestingly, unlike BAP2, all other analogues except 59 inhibited more than 50% of cell proliferation at a lower dose than their IC50 values in U87MG cells, indicating that these analogues can inhibit the clonogenic properties of the cells.
    Table 4. Cytotoxicity of the 23 Selected BAP2 Analogues in a Panel of Human GBM Cell Linesa
     IC50 (μM)
    compdU87MGA172NU04
    6 (BAP2)10.3 ± 2.316.8 ± 3.515.7 ± 3.4
    1517.7 ± 4.626.4 ± 4.119.9 ± 8.3
    1625.6 ± 5.035.0 ± 13.126.6 ± 0.7
    1717.0 ± 3.367.3 ± 46.815.5 ± 4.2
    185.6 ± 2.19.0 ± 3.45.0 ± 1.8
    19NSNSNS
    2048.5 ± 37.528.9 ± 3.018.7 ± 11.4
    2222.9 ± 8.116.8 ± 3.310.6 ± 3.8
    2329.1 ± 6.921.9 ± 7.19.8 ± 1.3
    3124.3 ± 11.020.2 ± 11.013.0 ± 2.2
    3215.1 ± 5.620.0 ± 8.612.8 ± 2.7
    3529.0 ± 9.328.4 ± 8.415.8 ± 10.3
    3626.4 ± 8.233.7 ± 13.510.4 ± 1.3
    4616.5 ± 7.619.5 ± 6.922.7 ± 8.2
    4728.8 ± 2.332.3 ± 1.630.6 ± 4.4

    5915.0 ± 3.511.3 ± 0.37.6 ± 3.1
    6776.3 ± 23.867.8 ± 6.426.2 ± 8.3
    6810.7 ± 0.811.0 ± 0.84.9 ± 1.0
    6924.9 ± 12.111.3 ± 0.13.8 ± 0.1

    7231.2 ± 2.132.1 ± 1.122.9 ± 6.5
    a

    Cytotoxicity was assessed by MTT assay. IC50 values are indicated as the mean ± SD (standard error) of at least three independent experiments for active compounds (IC50 < 20 μM). NS: not soluble in DMSO.

    Next, we tested the five BAP2 derivatives in HFF-1 normal human fibroblast cells to determine the therapeutic window of this series (Table 5; Supporting Information, Figure S3). Interestingly, BAP2 had the largest therapeutic window, with a 5.8-fold difference in potency in NU04 (15.7 ± 3.4 μM) versus HFF-1 cells (91.2 ± 13.1 μM). Compounds 59 and 68 demonstrated a 3.8-fold and 4.6-fold difference in potency, respectively, between cancer cells and normal cells. In the case of compound 18, potency was greater against the HFF-1 cells (3.4 ± 1.1 μM) than the NU04 cells (5.0 ± 1.8 μM). These results suggest that BAP2 and analogues may be effective in combination therapy because they may cause less off-target toxicity.
    Table 5. Cytotoxicity of Six BAP2 Analogues in a Human Fibroblast Cell Line HFF-1 and Comparison to NU04a
    compdNU04 (μM)HFF-1 (μM)fold difference
    BAP215.7 ± 3.491.2 ± 13.15.80
    185.0 ± 1.83.4 ± 1.10.67
    4622.7 ± 8.217.4 ± 3.50.77
    597.6 ± 3.129.2 ± 4.53.85
    684.9 ± 1.022.5 ± 8.04.57
    693.8 ± 0.131.8 ± 13.28.39
    a

    Cytotoxicity was assessed by MTT assay. IC50 values are indicated as the mean ± SD (standard error) of at least three independent experiments.

    BAP2 Analogues Stabilize PDI to Thermal Degradation

    To validate that our compounds interact with PDI and stabilize the protein to thermal denaturation, we further tested the compounds in the biochemical thermal shift assay. Compounds 18, 46, 59, 68, and 69 were tested at 100 μM against recombinant PDI, and an inactive compound 8 was used as a negative control in addition to DMSO. Typically, compounds that bind to a protein stabilize its secondary structure and increase the melting temperature; however, PACMA31, a validated PDI inhibitor, does not stabilize PDI. This may be explained by the irreversible covalent nature of binding to the reactive site cysteines. Because the bond is irreversibly covalent, it may not require additional interaction to inhibit PDI activity. On the other hand, estradiol, known to bind in the b′ domain of PDI and form critical interactions with His256,(39) stabilizes PDI to thermal denaturation.
    Similar to estradiol and BAP2, the analogues 46, 59, and 68 increased the melting temperature by more than 1 °C in a dose-dependent manner, suggesting that these compounds form important stabilizing interactions with PDI (Figure 4A,B, and Supporting Information, Figure S4). However, compounds 18 and 69 did not stabilize PDI in the thermal shift assay despite being potent inhibitors of PDI activity; these results, suggest that these compounds may interact in the active site of PDI instead of the hydrophobic pocket of the b′ domain. This suggests that BAP2 analogues 46, 59, and 68 may form critical interactions with PDI that PACMA31 does not form. To provide additional evidence to support our hypothesis, we prepared two mutants of PDI: H256A and C53S/C397S. The H256A mutant contains a point mutation from histidine to alanine at the key residue 256 where estradiol normally binds. The C53S/C397S mutant contains serine residues replacing one cysteine from each of the CGHC active sites. In the thermal shift assay, the stabilization by estradiol and BAP2 was abolished in the H256A mutant but not the C53S/C397S mutant (Figure 4C). Interestingly, the shift caused by analogues 46, 59, and 68 was not abolished by either mutation. This suggests that the histidine may be crucial for BAP2 binding, but other hydrophobic interactions are important for analogue binding and activity. Specifically, 46, 59, and 68 may react with the active site thiols. These results ultimately suggest that 46, 59, and 68 may be interacting with both the active site and b′ domain of PDI.
    The binding affinity of BAP2 to wild-type PDI is around 10 μM, tested with the thermal shift assay (Kd = 9.8) and isothermal calorimetry (ITC) (Kd = 9.1 μM) (Supporting Information, Figure S5). Binding affinities of analogues of BAP2, including 46 and 59, were unable to be determined via ITC due to poor solubility, suggesting further optimization of this series will be necessary. However, BAP2 binding affinity is similar to quercetin-3-rutinoside, another b′ domain PDI inhibitor (12.3 μM).(40)

    BAP2 Analogues Induce ER Stress in GBM Cells

    PDI plays an important role in regulating the ER stress response, a mechanism that triggers the UPR and ultimately balances ER homeostasis.(41) In this study, we hypothesized that inhibition of PDI by BAP2 analogues would exacerbate ER stress mechanisms by disrupting homeostatic balance, ultimately leading to cell death. To monitor whether the BAP2 analogues induce ER stress, we first investigated their effect on phosphorylation of eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2α (EIF2α) in U87MG and A172 cells (Figure 5A). EIF2α is a translation initiation factor downstream of the PERK arm of the UPR, and phosphorylation of EIF2α in response to ER stress leads to inhibition of protein synthesis.(41) Like tunicamycin, a protein glycosylation inhibitor, treatment with BAP2 analogues increased phosphorylation of EIF2α above basal levels in both GBM cell lines. Unexpectedly, PACMA31 did not induce phosphorylation of EIF2α. We also observed an increase in expression of GRP78 in response to PACMA31, BAP2, and analogues (Figure 5B). These results indicate that treatment of GBM cells with BAP2 analogues promotes ER stress, upregulates the UPR, and inhibits protein synthesis. Compound 46 significantly promotes the ER stress response in GBM cells. PDI expression was also measured and did not change upon treatment with PDI inhibitors.

    BAP2 Analogues Inhibit GBM Cell Migration

    PDI is involved in the migratory capabilities of glioma cells via the integrin outside-in pathway.(18) Therefore, inhibiting PDI may prevent GBM cell invasion and metastasis. To determine whether the BAP2 analogues could inhibit cell migration, we performed the wound healing assay in A172 cells. BAP2 inhibited wound healing at 10 μM, and all analogues, except 69, inhibited cell migration in a dose-dependent manner, similar to PACMA31 (Figure 6A).
    An additional transwell migration assay was performed to validate the migration of A172 cells in the presence of selected compounds, PACMA31, 6, 18, and 59 at subtoxic concentrations (Figure 6B). Cells were treated with the compounds for 4 h. All compounds inhibited migration at 30 μM, and 18 inhibited migration at 10 μM. We further examined the effect of the compounds on the expression level of migration markers including MMP2, MMP9, and p-FAK in U87MG cells at 10 μM for 48 h. Gelatin zymography and Western blot analysis of the conditioned media confirmed that PACMA31 and 68 inhibit MMP2 activity and secretion (Figure 6C,D). MMP2 expression in cells did not change upon BAP2 analogue treatment; however, MMP9 expression decreased in the presence of PACMA31, 18, 59, and 68 (Figure 6E). FAK phosphorylation did not change with BAP2 analogue treatment (Figure 6F). These results demonstrate that BAP2 analogues inhibit GBM cell migration via downregulation of MMP9 and decreased secretion of MMP2.

    BAP2 and Analogue 46 Induce ER Stress and Downregulate DNA Damage Response Genes

    Previously, with nascent RNA sequencing (Bru-seq), we demonstrated that BAP2 treatment of U87MG cells upregulated ER stress and UPR genes and decreased expression of DNA repair and DNA damage response (DDR) genes (unpublished). We performed Bru-seq on analogues 18 and 46 and found they had a similar effect on the cells (Tables 6–9; Supporting Information, Files 1 and 2). The transcription of ER stress response genes including DDIT3, CHAC1, ASNS, and XBP1 increased upon treatment with both compounds, although 18 increased transcription to a greater extent (Figure 7A). Furthermore, both compounds also decreased transcription of RAD51 (Figure 7B) and E2F1 (Figure 7C). Additionally, Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) was performed on the log 2-fold changes of the abundance ratios of protein expression between DMSO- and compound-treated U87MG cells. GSEA confirmed that both 18 and 46 treatment resulted in profiles that positively correlated with UPR and negatively correlated with E2F signaling (Figures 8–11; Supporting Information, Tables S2–S27). We applied Hallmark pathway analysis via GSEA and identified that genes with decreased transcription upon 46 treatment also correlated with epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition, TNFα signaling, and KRAS signaling (Supporting Information, Table S15).
    Table 6. Top 25 Protein-Coding Genes with Increased Transcription upon Treatment with 10 μM Compound 18

    PRLRprolactin receptor–2.6
    To further validate the GSEA results, proteomics with tandem mass tag multiplexing was performed in U87MG cells treated for 24 h with DMSO and 20 μM BAP2 or 18 (Supporting Information, File 3). GSEA revealed that BAP2 treatment was positively correlated with the G2M DNA damage checkpoint and negatively correlated with ribosomes and associated proteins. Furthermore, 18 treatment was positively correlated with an arsenic trioxide signature and negatively correlated with DNA replication (Figure 12, Supporting Information, File 4). These results suggest the analogues are targeting PDI and promoting a similar transcriptional response in the cells as BAP2. Long, noncoding RNAs (lncRNA) can act as transcriptional regulators(42) and impact glioma initiation and progression.(43) GSEA of the Bru-seq transcription profiles of 18 and 46 also revealed noncoding genes with increased or decreased transcription (Supporting Information, Tables S26–S29). Transcription of NMRAL2P, a transcribed unprocessed pseudogene and target of Nrf2,(44) increased upon both 18 (+2.72 log2 fold change) and 46 (+4.10 log2 fold change) treatment of U87MG cells.
    Additionally, PDI inhibition by 18 and 46 induces an immune response. Treatment of U87MG cells with 18 increases transcription of genes involved in the GO_ANTIGEN_PROCESSING_AND_PRESENTATION_OF_EXOGENOUS_PEPTIDE_ANTIGEN_VIA_MHC_CLASS_I gene set (NES = +2.37; FDR q-val = 0), and treatment with 46 correlates with the REACTOME_CLASS_I_MHC_MEDIATED_ANTIGEN_PROCESSING_PRESENTATION gene set (NES = +1.47; FDR q-val = 0.24). Furthermore, treatment with compound 18 correlates with both an inflammatory and immune response. PDI has been demonstrated to play a role in the immune response, and PDI is required for the degradation of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I, a protein responsible for antigen presentation that is essential for adaptive immunity.(45,46) On the other hand, another study demonstrated that PDI forms a key disulfide bond with the α2 domain of the MHC class I heavy chain to aid early folding of the complex,(47) and another PDI family member, ERp57, may also aid stabilization of the MHC class I heavy chain via disulfide bond formation.(48) Thus, the role of PDI in the immune response is complex and the upregulation of transcription in these pathways in response to PDI inhibition may be a feedback response to pathway inhibition.

    BAP2 Analogues Have Similar Gene Expression Signatures as Brazilin and HSP Inhibitors

    We analyzed the Bru-seq signatures of compound 18 and 46 for similarity to gene expression profiles of known drugs using the Connectivity Map (Supporting Information, Tables S30–S33).(49) The signatures of both compounds were similar to heterotetracyclic brazilin, an anti-inflammatory compound(50) that promotes apoptosis and inhibits cancer cell growth.(51,52) Furthermore, signatures of both compounds demonstrated a high level of correlation with several HSP inhibitors, including luminespib (NVP-AUY922) for compound 18, and luminespib (NVP-AUY922), geldanamycin, PU-H71, and BIIB021 for compound 46. These results further confirm that BAP2 analogues 18 and 46 inhibit ER chaperone activity in the cells.

    BAP2 Analogue Treatment Is Synergistic with Arsenic Trioxide

    Previously, we demonstrated that BAP2 treatment induces transcription of genes similar to that of arsenite treatment (unpublished). Furthermore, we observed increased expression of proteins involved in the response to arsenic oxide upon treatment with compound 18. Arsenic trioxide has been used to treat patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia,(53) and synergy between tetra-arsenic oxide and paclitaxel in cancer cells has been observed.(54)BAP2 and derivatives 13, 14, and 15 inhibit GBM cell proliferation synergistically with As2O3 (Supporting Information, Figure S6A). Synergistic combinations had a combination index value below 1 using the Chou–Talalay method (Supporting Information, Figures S6B and S6C).(55) Our results suggest that these BAP2 analogues may best function in combination with other drugs.

    BAP2 Analogue Treatment Synergizes with Radiation

    Because PDI inhibition and BAP2 treatment cause global downregulation of DNA damage repair genes, we next determined whether BAP2 analogues would synergize with radiation to decrease GBM cell viability. PDI inhibition radiosensitizes GBM cells (unpublished). The clonogenic survival assay demonstrated synergy upon combination of PDI inhibitors and ionizing radiation (IR) compared to either modality alone (Supporting Information, Figure S7). Both BAP2 and 68 treatment synergized with IR; however, PACMA31 at 0.05 μM did not. It is likely that the dose of PACMA31 was too low to demonstrate synergy because the enzymatic IC50 value of PACMA31 inhibition of PDI is around 10 μM. Therefore, the more potent BAP2 analogues likely synergize with IR by inhibiting PDI. These findings provide a strong rationale for the development of PDI inhibitors as agents to combine with DNA damage-inducing therapies such as IR.

    BAP2 Analogue Activity Varies against H256A Mutant PDI

    As we previously demonstrated, BAP2 requires His256 in the b′ domain for activity, similar to estradiol binding (unpublished). We also tested the BAP2 analogues in the PDI reductase assay (Figure 13A). The activity of BAP2 analogues, except 59, was reduced upon mutation of His256 to Ala as BAP2, suggesting the analogues also bind in the b′ domain of PDI and require His256 for activity. To further confirm their binding, we used the fluorescent dye, 1-anilinonaphthalene-8-sulfonic acid (ANS), which is known to bind and fluoresce selectively in the b′ domain of PDI.(56) As expected, BAP2 and active analogues hindered the ability of ANS to fluoresce at 370 nm, whereas PACMA31, which binds in the active site of PDI, and inactive BAP2 analogues (8 and 29) did not hinder dye fluorescence (Figure 13B). Compound 59 is active against the H256A mutant but competes with ANS for the b′ domain, further suggesting a complex binding mode. It is possible that 59 inhibits PDI by binding in between the a′ and b′ domains or binds in both sites. To address the potential role of thiol-dependent inhibition, we tested the BAP2 analogues after competition with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC). As a positive control, the activity of PACMA31 was significantly abolished after competition with NAC (Figure 13C). Activity of BAP2 and 68 were unaffected by up to 5 mM NAC. Activity of 46 and 59 was abolished by 5 mM NAC but not by lower concentrations, suggesting they may be attacked by the thiol groups on the cysteine active sites. For compound 59, this is further confirmed by the fact that activity is not dependent on His256. These results, in combination with the alanine mutation of His256, suggest that analogue 68 binds in the b′ domain of PDI to inhibit activity.

    BAP2 Analogues Interact with Hydrophobic Residues in the b′ Domain

    We hypothesized that BAP2 derivatives may interact with the b′ domain to enhance binding to PDI. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the replacement of residue His256 with Ala abolishes the activity of BAP2 and its analogues. Using a computational approach, we docked all BAP2 analogues into three PDI ligand binding sites, including two catalytic sites as well as the hydrophobic pocket in the b′ domain (Figure 14A). The catalytic sites contain reactive Cys56 and Cys397, where PACMA31 binds,(37) and the b′ domain contains a hydrophobic pocket for substrate recognition. Molecular docking demonstrated that BAP2 analogues preferentially interact with the b′ domain of PDI compared to catalytic sites, supporting the mutagenesis results (Figure 14B). Noncovalent docking of active BAP2 derivatives into the b′ domain results in binding affinity values of −6.6 and −6.7 kcal/mol for active compounds 49 and 68, respectively (Figure 15).
    Hydrogen bonding interaction between BAP2 derivatives and His256 of the b′ domain of PDI is critical for their PDI inhibitory activity. Previous studies demonstrated that His256 plays a key role in the binding of estradiol in the b′ domain.(39) Phe249 stabilizes the interaction with π–π stacking. The other key residues in the binding of BAP2 analogues with the b′ domain are Leu320 and Ile318, as demonstrated by the docking pose. π–Alkyl interactions of the benzene rings with these residues stabilize the structures in this binding site and contribute to the potency of BAP2 derivatives as PDI inhibitors.

    Discussion and Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In this study, we report a novel target, PDI, for a series of chalcones, perform an extensive SAR study, determine their activity on human glioblastoma cell lines, and propose their mechanism of action as allosteric inhibitors of the b′ domain of PDI. Electron-deficient olefins, such as Michael acceptors, are susceptible to reactions with nucleophiles, resulting in a covalent bond with threonine and cysteine residues of proteins.(57,58) For example, PACMA31, which was previously identified as a PDI inhibitor, irreversibly inhibits PDI through its propynoic acid amide moiety by covalently binding to cysteine residues in the active site,(37) and this is further supported by the results herein that demonstrate that PACMA31 inhibition of PDI is challenged by N-acetyl cysteine. We would expect chalcone analogues would also inhibit PDI via Michael addition reaction with the nucleophilic cysteines in the PDI active site because of their olefin structure. However, the activity of BAP2 and its analogues 46 and 68 is unaffected by NAC. Instead, their ability to inhibit PDI is abolished upon mutation of the key residue, His256, that is responsible for substrate-binding interactions in the b′ domain.(39,59) Furthermore, the stabilizing shift caused by BAP2 and analogues in the thermal shift assay is also abolished upon H256A mutation, and BAP2 and analogues compete with ANS for the b′ hydrophobic binding pocket of PDI. These results suggest that the b′ domain is at least critical for BAP2 analogue binding. It should be noted that the activity of some BAP2 analogues, such as 59, is not His256-dependent, and the electron-withdrawing sulfonamide may activate the olefin for nucleophilic attack. These findings indicate that BAP2 and analogues primarily use the hydrophobic pocket in the b′ domain to inhibit PDI.
    When the substituent on ring A is an electron-withdrawing group such as a sulfonamide, the carbonyl may be activated for a Michael addition with the thiols in the PDI active sites. Without an electron-withdrawing group on ring A, the carbonyl is a weak electrophile, and other hydrophobic interactions, such as the hydrogen bond with His256, may play a more important role instead. It remains to be determined whether b′ domain-binding analogues such as BAP2 and 46 also interact reversibly with the active site cysteines. As a whole, the mutagenesis evidence suggests that BAP2 and analogue 46 inhibit PDI not by attack on the weak Michael acceptor but by interaction with the hydrophobic binding pocket of PDI. This agrees with the recent findings that chalcones without any substituents on the olefin do not induce Nrf2, possibly because no effective alkylation reaction occurs between the electrophilic chalcone compound and the distinct cysteine residues in Keap1.(60) Finally, although all the tested chalcones contain the Michael accepting site, only a few are potent PDI inhibitors. Additionally, the SAR profile of the analogues was not flat, demonstrating that these compounds do not all bind the active site cysteines but have a more complex binding mode.
    Nascent RNA transcription analysis of BAP2 analogue treatment provided a blueprint of their effect on GBM cell transcription. Cells treated with BAP2 analogues 18 and 46 demonstrated increased transcription of genes related to the UPR after 4 h of treatment. The increased transcription of UPR genes suggests the compounds inhibit PDI in the cells, leading to an increase in the unfolded protein load. This result is consistent with the findings of another research group that treatment with 2′-hydroxy-2,3,5′-trimethoxychalcone induces the UPR in MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells.(61) Additionally, BAP2 analogues 18 and 46 decreased transcription of E2F targets. BAP2 downregulated protein expression of E2F1 (unpublished), and PDI knockdown was linked to reduced E2F expression (unpublished). These results provide further target engagement validation and suggest BAP2 analogues inhibit PDI activity in the cells.
    In addition to their role in tumor proliferation, PDI family members are involved in tumor immune recognition. Immune response proteins, such as antibodies, are secretory molecules and require maturation through the ER to be prepared for secretion. Tumors evade immune recognition by “shedding” key immune signal proteins from the tumor cell surface. Neutrophil l-selectin adhesion to lymphocytes is dependent on disulfide bonds. PDI inhibition promotes neutrophil l-selectin shedding, suggesting that PDI promotes signaling for immune pathways to eliminate tumor cells.(62) Furthermore, PDI has been shown to promote antibody production and the humoral immune response in GM-CSF-secreting cancer cells.(63) However, ERp5 is necessary for shedding of the soluble major histocompatibility complex class-I-related ligand MICA and thus allows the tumor to evade the immune response.(64) ERp5, along with ADAM10 (a disintegrin and metalloproteinase 10), were also found to block the antitumor immune response in classic Hodgkin’s lymphoma by shedding NKG2D (natural killer group 2D) receptor ligands.(65) Thus, the increase in transcription of MHC-related genes that we observe upon treatment with BAP2 analogues may be a response to MHC complex degradation. Clearly, thiol-based redox reactions play a key role in regulating the humoral immune response; however, the precise role of PDI in each pathway remains to be defined.
    In summary, we explored the structure of BAP2 by modifying the substituents around ring A and ring B and identified potent analogues that may be promising treatment strategies for GBM. We identified five compounds that were more potent and cytotoxic than the lead BAP2, as well as compounds that induced ER stress and inhibited GBM cell migration and MMP9 expression. Especially, the analogues 18 and 46 induced genes involved in the UPR and decreased expression of E2F target genes, validating PDI inhibition in the cells. Additionally, we demonstrated the therapeutic window afforded with the derivatives and the potential for combination with As2O3. Furthermore, preliminary results suggest that the interaction between the compounds and PDI may rely on more than a nucleophilic attack with the Michael acceptor region of the compound, and hydrophobic interaction in the b′ domain of PDI may play the most significant role. Further structural studies are needed to confirm the binding pose of the BAP2 analogues. Our data demonstrate that PDI inhibitors should be tested in combination with other targeted agents as well as cytotoxic chemotherapy to deliver significant beneficial effects.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Methods

    All commercial chemicals and solvents were reagent grade and used without further purification unless otherwise specified. Analytical thin layer chromatography was performed on Merck precoated plates (Silica Gel 60 F254) to follow the course of reactions. Proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectroscopy was performed on a Bruker Ultrashield 300 MHz, a Bruker Ascend 400 MHz, or 500 MHz Varian NMR spectrometer. Chemical shifts (δ) are reported in parts per million (ppm) relative to residual undeuterated solvent. The following abbreviations were used to describe peak splitting patterns when appropriate: s (singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet), q (quartet), m (multiplet), bs (broad singlet), dd (doublet of doublets), ddd (doublet of doublet of doublets), dt (doublet of triplets), and td (triplet of doublets). Coupling constant (J) is shown in hertz (Hz). Mass spectra were obtained on a Shimadzu LCMS-2020 liquid chromatography mass spectrometer using the electron spray ionization (ESI) method. HPLC was used to determine purity by Shimadzu HPLC Test Kit C18 column (3 μm, 4.6 mm × 50 mm) under the following gradient elution condition: mobile phase A of acetonitrile/water (10–95%) or mobile phase B of methanol/water (10–95%). The purity was established by integration of the areas of major peaks detected at 254 nm, and all tested compounds have ≥95% purity. Flash chromatography was performed using a Biotage Isolera One flash purification system.

    Synthesis of Acetophenones 3a–n and Benzaldehyde 4-b

    1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)ethan-1-one (3a)

    A mixture of 4′-hydroxyacetophenone (2.0 g, 14.4 mmol), methyl iodide (2.25 g, 15.8 mmol), and potassium carbonate (5.96 g, 43.2 mmol) in acetone (150 mL) was refluxed overnight. The resulting mixture was filtered off to remove potassium salt, and the filtrate was evaporated to dryness. The residue was purified using column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1) to obtain 3a as an off-white solid (2.1 g, 97%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 7.96 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.95 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 3.89 (s, 3H), 2.58 (s, 3H).

    4-Acetylbenzenesulfonamide (3b)

    To a solution of 4-acetylbenzenesulfonyl chloride (500 mg, 2.29 mmol) was added 0.5 M ammonia in dioxane (22.9 mL, 11.4 mmol). The resulting suspension was stirred at room temperature. After the reaction was completed, the solvent was removed, and the residue was taken up in EtOAc. The organic phase was washed with satd NH4Cl (aq) and then brine, and removal of solvent in vacuo afforded 3b as a white solid (312 mg, 68%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.12 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.95 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.55 (s, 2H), 2.63 (s, 3H). MS (ESI): m/z 198 (M – H)−.

    4-Acetyl-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (3c)

    A mixture of 4-acetylbenzenesulfonyl chloride (200 mg, 0.92 mmol), dimethylamine (2 M in THF, 0.5 mL, 1.0 mmol), and triethylamine (185 mg, 1.83 mmol) in anhydrous THF (10 mL) was stirred at room temperature overnight. Brine was added, and the reaction mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 times). The combined organic layer was washed with brine (100 mL), dried over Na2SO4, and filtered. Removal of solvent in vacuo gave 3c as an off-white solid (152 mg, 73%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.11 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.88 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 2.74 (s, 6H), 2.67 (s, 3H). MS (ESI): m/z 228 (M + H)+.

    4-Acetyl-N,N-diethylbenzenesulfonamide (3d)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 3c was used with 4-acetylbenzenesulfonyl chloride (200 mg, 0.92 mmol), diethylamine (73 mg, 1.0 mmol), and triethylamine (185 mg, 1.83 mmol) to obtain 3d as an ivory solid (192 mg, 82%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.06 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.91 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 3.27 (q, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H), 2.65 (s, 3H), 1.14 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 6H). MS (ESI): m/z 256 (M + H)+.

    4-Acetyl-N,N-dipropylbenzenesulfonamide (3e)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 3c was used with 4-acetylbenzenesulfonyl chloride (200 mg, 0.92 mmol), dipropylamine (101 mg, 1.0 mmol), and triethylamine (185 mg, 1.83 mmol) to obtain 3e as a yellow oil (222 mg, 86%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.06 (dt, J = 8.7, 1.8 Hz, 2H), 7.90 (dt, J = 8.7, 1.8 Hz, 2H), 3.14–3.07 (m, 4H), 2.65 (s, 3H), 1.55 (sextet, J = 7.5 Hz, 4H), 0.87 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 6H).

    4-Acetyl-N,N-dibutylbenzenesulfonamide (3f)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 3c was used with 4-acetylbenzenesulfonyl chloride (300 mg, 1.37 mmol), dibutylamine (193 mg, 1.50 mmol), and triethylamine (277 mg, 2.74 mmol) to obtain 3f as a yellow oil (363 mg, 85%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.06 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 2H), 7.90 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 3.14 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 4H), 2.65 (s, 3H), 1.58–1.44 (m, 4H), 1.29 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 4H), 0.90 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 6H). MS (ESI): m/z 312 (M + H)+.

    4-Acetyl-N,N-dipentylbenzenesulfonamide (3g)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 3c was used with 4-acetylbenzenesulfonyl chloride (200 mg, 0.92 mmol), diamylamine (157 mg, 1.0 mmol), and triethylamine (185 mg, 1.83 mmol) to obtain 3g as a yellow oil (268 mg, 86%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.06 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.89 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2H), 3.18–3.06 (m, 3H), 3.03–2.86 (m, 1H), 2.65 (s, 3H), 1.56–1.36 (m, 4H), 1.31–1.18 (m, 6H), 0.92–0.83 (m, 8H). MS (ESI): m/z 340 (M + H)+.

    4-Acetyl-N-cyclopropylbenzenesulfonamide (3h)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 3c was used with 4-acetylbenzenesulfonyl chloride (300 mg, 1.37 mmol), cyclopropylamine (85 mg, 1.50 mmol), and triethylamine (278 mg, 2.74 mmol) to obtain 3h as a white solid (245 mg, 75%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.10 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 8.01 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 4.94 (s, 1H), 2.67 (s, 3H), 2.34–2.23 (m, 1H), 0.63–0.61 (m, 4H). MS (ESI): m/z 238 (M – H)−.

    4-Acetyl-N-phenylbenzenesulfonamide (3i)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 3c was used with 4-acetylbenzenesulfonyl chloride (300 mg, 1.37 mmol), aniline (139 mg, 1.50 mmol), and triethylamine (277 mg, 2.74 mmol) to obtain 3i as an off-white solid (239 mg, 63%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 7.99 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2H), 7.85 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 2H), 7.28–7.23 (m, 2H), 7.16–7.06 (m, 3H), 2.61 (s, 3H). MS (ESI): m/z 274 (M – H)−.

    N-(4-Acetylphenyl)-4-nitrobenzenesulfonamide (3j)

    A solution of 4-nitrobenzenesulfonyl chloride (500 mg, 2.3 mmol) in anhydrous DCM (5 mL) was added dropwise over 10 min to a solution of 4-aminoacetophenone (335 mg, 2.5 mmol) and pyridine (196 mg, 2.5 mmol) in anhydrous DCM (5 mL). The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. Then 1 N HCl solution was added until the pH of the aqueous phase became about 2, and the aqueous phase was then extracted with DCM (3 times). The combined organic extracts were washed with brine, then dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The crude product was recrystallized from MeOH to give 3j as a pink solid (557 mg, 77%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 11.17 (s, 1H), 8.39 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 8.08 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 7.86 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 7.24 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 7.16 (dd, J = 4.9, 3.9 Hz, 1H), 2.48 (s, 3H). MS (ESI): m/z 319 (M – H)−.

    N-(4-Acetylphenyl)thiophene-2-carboxamide (3k)

    2-Thiophenecarboxylic acid (640 mg, 5.0 mmol) and SOCl2 (2–3 mL) were reacted overnight at room temperature and evaporated to give the corresponding reactive acyl chloride. The crude acyl chloride was dissolved in DCM (2–3 mL) and treated with 4-aminoacetophenone (675 mg, 5.0 mmol) and pyridine (2 mL) in DCM. The reaction mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 2 h. Then the mixture was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the resulting precipitate was washed with saturated NaHCO3 (aq). Extraction of the saturated NaHCO3 layer with ethyl acetate (3 times) yielded 3k as a solid (1.1 g, 90%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.00 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 7.76 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H), 7.70 (d, J = 3.1 Hz, 1H), 7.61 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 2H), 7.16 (dd, J = 4.9, 3.9 Hz, 1H), 2.61 (s, 3H). MS (ESI): m/z 266 (M – H)−.

    4-Acetylphenyl Thiophene-2-carboxylate (3l)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 3k was used with 2-thiophenecarboxylic acid (640 mg, 5.0 mmol) and 4-hydroxyacetophenone (675 mg, 5.0 mmol) to obtain 3l as solid (1.1 g, 86%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.06 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 8.02 (d, J = 3.8 Hz, 1H), 7.72 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 1H), 7.36 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 7.24–7.18 (m, 1H), 2.64 (s, 3H).

    N-(4-Acetylphenyl)thiophene-2-sulfonamide (3m)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 3k was used with 2-thiophenesulfonic acid (910 mg, 5.0 mmol) and 4-aminoacetophenone (675 mg, 5.0 mmol) to obtain 3m as solid (1.2 g, 87%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 7.93 (dd, J = 5.0, Hz, 1H), 7.88 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 7.66 (dd, J = 3.7, Hz, 1H), 7.27 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 7.14 (t, J = 4.8, Hz, 1H), 2.50 (s, 3H).

    1-(3-Bromo-4-(hydroxymethyl)phenyl)ethan-1-one (3n)

    A solution of 3′-bromo-4′-methyl acetophenone (300 mg, 1.407 mmol), N-bromosuccinimide (275 mg, 1.548 mmol), and AIBN (46 mg, 0.28 mmol) in MeCN (10 mL) was refluxed for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the mixture was filtered through a silica pad and washed with DCM. After concentration, CaCO3 (422 mg, 4.221 mmol) was added to the residue, followed by addition of 1,4-dioxane/water (5 mL/5 mL). The resulting suspension was heated under reflux for 16 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solid was removed by filtration. The filtrate was extracted with EtOAc, and the organic phase was washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The resulting residue was purified by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 5:1) to obtain 3n as a white solid (160 mg, 50%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.14 (d, J = 1.7 Hz, 1H), 7.93 (dd, J = 8.0, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 7.65 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 4.82 (s, 2H), 2.62 (s, 3H), 2.13 (bs, 1H).

    Methyl 3-Formylbenzoate (4a)

    A solution of 3-carboxybenzaldehyde (500 mg, 3.3 mmol) in MeOH:H2O (10:1, 10 mL) was treated with Cs2CO3 (542 mg, 1.7 mmol) and stirred at room temperature. After stirring 18 h, the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure at 60 °C. The resulting residue was suspended in anhydrous DMF (5 mL) and treated with methyl iodide (0.41 mL, 6.7 mmol). After stirring at room temperature for 2 h, the mixture was poured into water and extracted with EtOAc. The organic extract was combined, washed with water, saturated NaHCO3 (aq), dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated. The residue was purified using column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1) to obtain 4a as a white solid (374 mg, 68%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 10.09 (s, 1H), 8.54 (s, 1H), 8.31 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 8.09 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.64 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 3.97 (s, 3H).

    4-(1H-Benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)benzaldehyde (4b)

    A solution of 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (300 mg, 2.42 mmol), benzimidazole (238 mg, 2.01 mmol), and potassium carbonate (557 mg, 4.03 mmol) in DMF (5 mL) was heated at 100 °C overnight. After cooling to room temperature, water was added and the aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc. The combined organic phase was washed with water and brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The resulting residue was purified using column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 1:1) to obtain 4b as a white solid (375 mg, 70%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 10.11 (s, 1H), 8.19 (s, 1H), 8.12 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 7.91–7.89 (m, 1H), 7.74 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 7.63–7.61 (m, 1H), 7.40–7.38 (m, 2H). MS (ESI): m/z 223 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of Chalcone Analogues 5–72

    (E)-3-(3-(3-Hydroxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (5)

    Boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 781 mg, 5.5 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of 3′-hydroxyacetophenone (150 mg, 1.1 mmol) and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (289 mg, 2.2 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (10 mL), and the reaction mixture was heated at 80 °C for 14–24 h. After cooling, the resultant solution was partitioned with EtOAc, washed with 10% HCl (aq), distilled water, and brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified using column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1, 1:1) to obtain 5 as an ivory solid (170 mg, 62%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 9.82 (s, 1H), 8.49 (s, 1H), 8.18 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.03 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, 1H), 7.89 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.72 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.68–7.64 (m, 2H), 7.49 (s, 1H), 7.38 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.08 (dd, J = 8.0, 2.4 Hz, 1H). MS (ESI): m/z 248 (M – H)−. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 98%.

    (E)-3-(3-(4-Hydroxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (6)

    8 (200 mg, 0.76 mmol) and pyridine hydrochloride (890 mg, 7.6 mmol) were combined in a reaction vessel and heated at 210 °C. After stirring overnight, the resultant solution was cooled to room temperature and added to ice–water (10 mL). The pH of the aqueous solution was adjusted to 7–8 with satd Na2CO3 (aq). The precipitate formed was removed by filtration. The filtrate was partitioned with DCM, and the organic layer was washed with distilled water, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The resulting residue was purified using column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1, 1:1, EtOAc) to obtain 6 as a yellow solid (70 mg, 37%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 10.46 (s, 1H), 8.48 (s, 1H), 8.16 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.11 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 8.08 (d, J = 15.2 Hz, 1H), 7.87 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 7.78 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.65 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.91 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H). MS (ESI): m/z 250 (M + H)+, 248 (M – H)−. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 96%.

    (E)-3-(3-(3-Methoxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (7)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 3a was used with 5 (50 mg, 0.20 mmol), methyl iodide (31 mg, 0.22 mmol), and potassium carbonate (83 mg, 0.60 mmol) to obtain 7 as a yellow solid (48 mg, 91%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.51 (s, 1H), 8.20 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.09 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, 1H), 7.90 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.81 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.76 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.69–7.65 (m, 2H), 7.51 (t, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.27 (dd, J = 8.4, 2.8 Hz, 1H), 3.86 (s, 3H). MS (ESI): m/z 264 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase B): purity 95%.

    (E)-3-(3-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (8)

    To a stirred solution of 3a (1.0 g, 6.7 mmol) and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (0.90 g, 6.7 mmol) in anhydrous EtOH (2 mL) was added 60% NaOH (10 mL) dropwise over 20 min on ice. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2–3 h and cooled at 4 °C for 1–2 h. The resulting residue was diluted with cold water. The precipitate that formed was filtered, washed with cold water, dried in air, and recrystallized from MeOH to obtain 8 as a white solid (1.25g, 71%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.34 (s, 1H), 8.13 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.10 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 8.00 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.79 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.71 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.58 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.03 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 2H), 3.75 (s, 3H). MS (ESI): m/z 264 (M + H)+, 296 (M + Na)+. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 95%.

    (E)-3-(3-(4-Aminophenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (9)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 8 was used with 4′-aminoacetophenone (200 mg, 1.5 mmol) and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (200 mg, 1.5 mmol) to obtain 9 as a yellow solid (174 mg, 47%) after neutralization using 10% HCl, filtration, and recrystallization from MeOH. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.45 (s, 1H), 8.13 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.03 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.96 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 7.85 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.63(t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (d, J = 15.3 Hz, 1H), 6.63 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 6.21 (s, 2H). MS (ESI): m/z 249 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 96%.

    (E)-3-(3-(4-Bromophenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (10)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 582 mg, 4.0 mmol), 4′-bromoacetophenone (150 mg, 0.8 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (215 mg, 1.6 mmol) to obtain 10 as a yellow solid (176 mg, 71%) after filtration and recrystallization from MeOH. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.50 (s, 1H), 8.20 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.13 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 8.10 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.90 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.81 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.78 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.67 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H). MS (ESI): m/z 313 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 95%.

    (E)-3-(3-(4-Morpholinophenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (11)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 678 mg, 4.8 mmol), 4-morpholinoacetophenone (200 mg, 1.0 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (259 mg, 1.9 mmol) to obtain 11 as an orange solid (60 mg, 20%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 2:1, 1:1, EtOAc). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.48 (s, 1H), 8.17 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.11 (d, J = 11.2 Hz, 2H), 8.09 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, 1H), 7.87 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.67 (d, J = 16.0, 1H), 7.65 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.04 (d, J = 11.2 Hz, 2H), 3.75 (t, J = 4.8 Hz, 4H). 3.35 (t, J = 4.8 Hz, 4H). MS (ESI): m/z 319 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 96%.

    (E)-3-(3-Oxo-3-(4-(piperidin-1-yl)phenyl)prop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (12)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 852 mg, 6.0 mmol), piperidinoacetophenone (248 mg, 1.2 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (325 mg, 2.4 mmol) to obtain 12 as a green solid (253 mg, 67%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1, 2:1, 1:1, EtOAc). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.46 (s, 1H), 8.16 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H), 8.17–8.05 (m, 3H), 7.86 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.68–7.62 (m, 2H), 6.99 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 2H), 3.42 (s, 4H), 1.60 (s, 6H). MS (ESI): m/z 317 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 98%.

    (E)-4-(3-(3-Cyanophenyl)acryloyl)benzenesulfonamide (13)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 463 mg, 3.26 mmol), 3b (130 mg, 0.65 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (171 mg, 1.31 mmol) to obtain 13 as an off-white solid (80 mg, 39%) after extraction and crystallization from EtOH. 1H NMR (300 MHz, acetone-d6) δ: 8.34 (s, 1H), 8.33 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 8.17 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H), 8.08 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 8.07 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 7.87 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.85 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.71 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 6.80 (bs, 2H). MS (ESI): m/z 311 (M – H)−. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 98%.

    (E)-4-(3-(3-Cyanophenyl)acryloyl)-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (14)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 312 mg, 2.2 mmol), 3c (100 mg, 0.44 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (115 mg, 0.88 mmol) to obtain 14 as a light-beige solid (102 mg, 68%) after extraction and crystallization from EtOH. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.16 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.95 (s, 1H), 7.94 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.87 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.81 (d, J = 15.9 Hz, 1H), 7.73 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.58 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (d, J = 15.9 Hz, 1H), 2.77 (s, 6H). MS (ESI): m/z 363 (M + Na)+. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 96%.

    (E)-4-(3-(3-Cyanophenyl)acryloyl)-N,N-diethylbenzenesulfonamide (15)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 278 mg, 2.0 mmol), 3d (100 mg, 0.39 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (102 mg, 0.78 mmol) to obtain 15 as an ivory solid (67 mg, 47%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 5:1, 3:1). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.12 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.96 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.94 (s, 1H), 7.86 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.80 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, 1H), 7.72 (dt, J = 7.6, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 7.58 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.54 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 3.30 (q, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H), 1.16 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 6H). MS (ESI): m/z 369 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 99%.

    (E)-4-(3-(3-Cyanophenyl)acryloyl)-N,N-dipropylbenzenesulfonamide (16)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 250 mg, 1.8 mmol), 3e (100 mg, 0.35 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (93 mg, 0.71 mmol) to obtain 16 as an ivory solid (67 mg, 47%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 10:1, 5:1). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.12 (dt, J = 8.7, 1.8 Hz, 2H), 7.99–7.93 (m, 3H), 7.86 (dt, J = 7.8, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 7.80 (d, J = 15.7 Hz, 1H), 7.72 (dt, J = 7.8, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 7.58 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (d, J = 15.9 Hz, 1H), 3.18–3.08 (m, 4H), 1.57 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 4H), 0.89 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 6H). MS (ESI): m/z 397 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 98%.

    (E)-N,N-Dibutyl-4-(3-(3-cyanophenyl)acryloyl)benzenesulfonamide (17)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 342 mg, 2.4 mmol), 3f (150 mg, 0.48 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (126 mg, 0.96 mmol) to obtain 17 as an off-white solid (116 mg, 57%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 5:1). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.12 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 2H), 7.99–7.92 (m, 3H), 7.86 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.80 (d, J = 15.7 Hz, 1H), 7.72 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.58 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (d, J = 15.9 Hz, 1H), 3.16 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 4H), 1.56–1.45 (m, 4H), 1.30 (sextet, J = 7.5 Hz, 4H), 0.91 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 6H). MS (ESI): m/z 425 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 96%.

    (E)-4-(3-(3-Cyanophenyl)acryloyl)-N,N-dipentylbenzenesulfonamide (18)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 209 mg, 1.47 mmol), 3g (100 mg, 0.29 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (77 mg, 0.59 mmol) to obtain 18 as a white solid (44 mg, 33%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 10:1). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.12 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.99–7.92 (m, 3H), 7.86 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.80 (d, J = 15.7 Hz, 1H), 7.72 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.57 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.59–7.50 (m, 1H), 3.21–3.09 (m, 3H), 3.06–2.91 (m, 1H), 1.71–1.39 (m, 4H), 1.42–1.06 (m, 6H), 0.92–0.84 (m, 8H). MS (ESI): m/z 453 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase B): purity 98%.

    (E)-4-(3-(3-Cyanophenyl)acryloyl)-N-cyclopropylbenzenesulfonamide (19)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 296 mg, 2.09 mmol), 3h (100 mg, 0.42 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (109 mg, 0.84 mmol) to obtain 19 as an off-white solid (16 mg, 11%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.52 (s, 1H), 8.38 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 2H), 8.22 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 8.14 (s, 1H), 8.14 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.99 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.93 (d, J = 7.1 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 15.8 Hz, 1H), 7.69 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 2.16 (bs, 1H), 0.55–0.36 (m, 4H). MS (ESI): m/z 351 (M – H)−. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 95%.

    (E)-4-(3-(3-Cyanophenyl)acryloyl)-N-phenylbenzenesulfonamide (20)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 258 mg, 1.82 mmol), 3i (100 mg, 0.36 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (95 mg, 0.73 mmol) to obtain 20 as a light-yellow solid (35 mg, 25%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 5:1, 3:1). 1H NMR (300 MHz, acetone-d6) δ: 9.17 (bs, 1H), 8.34 (s, 1H), 8.28 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2H), 8.17 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H), 8.05 (d, J = 15.8 Hz, 1H), 7.97 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.88–7.81 (m, 2H), 7.71 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.32–7.24 (m, 4H), 7.13 (t, J = 6.1 Hz, 1H).     (E)-3-(3-(4-Fluoro-2-hydroxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (21)

    (E)-3-(3-(3-Fluoro-4-hydroxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (23)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 852 mg, 6.0 mmol), 3′-fluoro-4′-hydroxyacetophenone (189 mg, 1.2 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (325 mg, 2.4 mmol) to obtain 23 as a pink solid (228 mg, 71%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1, 1:1, EtOAc). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.49 (s, 1H), 8.17 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H), 8.08 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 8.03 (d, J = 12.3 Hz, 1H), 7.94 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 7.88 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.71 (d, J = 15.8 Hz, 1H), 7.70–7.65 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.10 (t, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 3.56 (s, 1H).     (E)-3-(3-(3-Hydroxy-4-methoxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (25)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 852 mg, 6.0 mmol), 3′-hydroxy-4′-methoxyacetophenone (200 mg, 1.2 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (315 mg, 2.4 mmol) to obtain 25 as a yellow solid (233 mg, 70%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 9.40 (s, 1H), 8.47 (s, 1H), 8.17 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.05 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.88 (dd, J = 7.6, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 7.80 (dd, J = 8.4, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.68 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.65 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.07 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (s, 3H).     (E)-3-(3-(4-Hydroxy-3-methoxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (26)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 853 mg, 6.0 mmol), 4′-hydroxy-3′-methoxyacetophenone (200 mg, 1.2 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (315 mg, 2.4 mmol) to obtain 26 as a yellow solid (240 mg, 72%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 10.11 (s, 1H), 8.47 (s, 1H), 8.18 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 8.08 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.88–7.83 (m, 2H), 7.69 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.65–7.63 (m, 2H), 6.92 (dd, J = 8.4, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 3.88 (s, 3H).     (E)-3-(3-(3,4-Dimethoxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (27)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 3a was used with 25 (60 mg, 0.22 mmol), methyl iodide (33 mg, 0.24 mmol), and potassium carbonate (89 mg, 0.64 mmol) to obtain 27 as a yellow solid (57 mg, 90%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.48 (s, 1H), 8.19 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 8.11 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.96 (dd, J = 8.4, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.89 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.72 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.66 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.12 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 3.88 (s, 3H), 3.86 (s, 3H). MS (ESI): m/z 294 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase B): purity 98%.

    (E)-3-(3-(4-Chloro-3-fluorophenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (28)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 852 mg, 6.0 mmol), 4′-chloro-3′-fluoroacetophenone (214 mg, 1.2 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (325 mg, 2.4 mmol) to obtain 28 as a yellowish-green solid (145 mg, 42%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 5:1, 4:1, 3:1, EtOAc). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.53 (s, 1H), 8.27–8.21 (m, 2H), 8.12 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 8.06 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H), 7.93 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.94–7.79 (m, 2H), 7.69 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H). MS (ESI): m/z 284 (M – H)−. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 99.7%.

    (E)-3-(3-Oxo-3-(pyrazin-2-yl)prop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (29)

    2-Acetyl pyrazine (150 mg, 1.2 mmol) and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (161 mg, 1.2 mmol) were dissolved in pyridine (1 mL). Diethylamine (0.13 mL, 1.2 mmol) was added into the reaction mixture, and the resulting mixture was heated at 80–120 °C for 2 h. After cooling, the reaction residue was poured into ice–water and acidified to pH 3 using a few drops of acetic acid. The precipitate that formed was filtered off and crystallized from EtOH to obtain 29 as an ivory solid (107 mg, 37%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 9.39 (s, 1H), 8.81 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 8.72 (bs, 1H), 8.25 (d, J = 16.2 Hz, 1H), 8.01 (s, 1H), 7.94–7.89 (m, 2H), 7.71 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.57 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H). MS (ESI): m/z 236 (M + H)+. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 96%.

    (E)-N-(4-(3-(3-Cyanophenyl)acryloyl)phenyl)-4-nitrobenzenesulfonamide (30)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with 3j (100 mg, 0.31 mmol), boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 222 mg, 1.6 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (81 mg, 0.62 mmol) to obtain 30 as a yellowish solid (46 mg, 34%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1) followed by recrystallization from EtOH. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 11.24 (s, 1H), 8.46 (s, 1H), 8.40 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 8.15 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 8.11 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 8.10 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 8.03 (d, J = 15.7 Hz, 1H), 7.89 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.69 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.66 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.29 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H). MS (ESI): m/z 432 (M – H)−. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 95%.

    (E)-(4-(3-(3-Cyanophenyl)acryloyl)phenyl)boronic acid (31)

    To a solution of 10 (150 mg, 0.48 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (10 mL) were added bis(pinacolato)diboron (243 mg, 0.96 mmol), PdCl2(dppf) (35 mg, 0.048 mmol), and potassium acetate (141 mg, 1.44 mmol), and the mixture was heated to reflux under N2 (g) overnight. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was filtered through Celite and washed with EtOAc. The filtrate was washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The resulting residue was purified by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 5:1) to obtain the intermediate as an ivory solid (116 mg, 67%). The intermediate (31a, 100 mg, 0.278 mmol) was immediately added to a solution of THF (1 mL) and H2O (1 mL) at room temperature. To the mixture was added NaIO4 (178 mg, 0.835 mmol), and the reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. To the resulting slurry was added 1 N HCl, and the mixture was allowed to stir for 4 h. Then, the residue was transferred to a separating funnel, and the product was extracted from the aqueous mixture with EtOAc. The combined organic phase was washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The crude solid was purified by trituration with hexane followed by crystallization from DCM to obtain 31 as an ivory solid (24 mg, 31%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, acetone-d6) δ: 8.37 (s, 1H), 8.20–8.16 (m, 3H), 8.11 (d, J = 15.7 Hz, 1H), 8.06 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2H), 7.88–7.80 (m, 2H), 7.72 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.47 (s, 1H). HPLC (mobile phase A + FA): purity 95%.

    (E)-3-(3-oxo-3-(4-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)phenyl)prop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (31a, the intermediate)

    1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.00 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2H), 7.96–7.93 (m, 3H), 7.85 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H), 7.76 (d, J = 15.8 Hz, 1H), 7.69 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.58 (d, J = 16.2 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 1.37 (s, 12H). MS (ESI): m/z 360 (M + H)+.

    (E)-4-(3-(3-Fluoro-4-hydroxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzonitrile (35)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 426 mg, 6.0 mmol), 3′-acetophenone (248 mg, 1.2 mmol), and 3-cyanobenzaldehyde (325 mg, 2.4 mmol) to obtain 35 as a pink solid (43 mg, 27%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1, 2:1, 1:1, EtOAc). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.51 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 8.49 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, 1H), 8.44 (dd, J = 12.4, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 8.35 (dd, J = 8.4, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 8.34 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 8.15 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.52 (t, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H).     (E)-3-(3-(4-Nitrophenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzoic Acid (38)

    (E)-3-(3-(3-Hydroxy-4-methoxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzoic Acid (42)

    (E)-3-(3-(3-Fluoro-4-hydroxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzoic Acid (43)

MS (ESI): m/z 287 (M + H)+, 285 (M – H)−. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 98%.

    (E)-3-(3-(4-Hydroxy-3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzoic Acid (44)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 215 mg, 1.5 mmol), 4′-hydroxy-3′-(trifluoromethyl)acetophenone (60 mg, 0.30 mmol), and 3-carboxybenzaldehyde (70 mg, 0.50 mmol) to obtain 44 as a light-yellow solid (46 mg, 46%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1, 2:1, 1:1, EtOAc). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.38–8.31 (m, 3H), 8.16 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 8.05 (d, J = 15.9 Hz, 1H), 7.99 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.79 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 7.59 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.17 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H). MS (ESI): m/z 387 (M + H)+, 385 (M – H)−. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 99%.

    (E)-3-(3-(4-((4-Nitrophenyl)sulfonamido)phenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzoic Acid (45)

    NaOH (6 mg, 0.26 mmol) was added to a solution of 53 (60 mg, 0.13 mmol) in a mixture of THF:H2O (1:1, 10 mL), and the reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The solution was acidified with 2 M HCl (aq) and extracted with EtOAc. The organic layer was washed with brine and concentrated. The crude solid was dissolved in saturated NaHCO3 (aq) and extracted with EtOAc. The water layer was acidified with acetic acid, and the formed precipitate was filtered off to obtain 45 as a yellow solid (50 mg, 86%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 8.26–8.19 (m, 3H), 7.99–7.89 (m, 4H), 7.84 (d, J = 16.5 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.60 (d, J = 15.5 Hz, 1H), 7.45 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 6.88 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H). MS (ESI): m/z 451 (M – H)−. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 99%.

    Methyl-(E)-3-(3-(3-hydroxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzoate (46)

    37 (50 mg, 0.19 mmol) was dissolved in dry MeOH (4 mL), a catalytic amount of sulfuric acid (3 drops) was added, and the reaction mixture was refluxed overnight. After cooling to room temperature, the residue was neutralized with 2N NaOH, concentrated in vacuo, and dissolved in EtOAc. The organic layer was washed with water and brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated to give the crude product. The crude product was further crystallized from EtOH to give 46 as an off-white solid (13 mg, 25%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ: 9.82 (s, 1H), 8.39 (s, 1H), 8.19 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 8.02 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.96 (d, J = 15.9 Hz, 1H), 7.78 (d, J = 15.8 Hz, 1H), 7.70–7.58 (m, 2H), 7.49 (s, 1H), 7.39 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H), 7.08 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 3.90 (s, 3H). MS (ESI): m/z 283 (M + H)+, 281 (M – H)−. HPLC (mobile phase A): purity 96%.

    Methyl-(E)-3-(3-(4-hydroxyphenyl)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)benzoate (47)

    The procedure applied to the synthesis of 5 was used with boron trifluoride etherate (48% BF3, 521 mg, 3.67 mmol), 4-hydroxyacetophenone (100 mg, 0.73 mmol), and 4a (241 mg, 1.47 mmol) to obtain 47 as a light-yellow solid (125 mg, 60%) after purification by column chromatography (n-hexane:EtOAc = 3:1). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.34 (s, 1H), 8.07 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.03 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.85–7.78 (m, 2H), 7.61 (d, J = 15.7 Hz, 1H), 7.51 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 6.95 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 5.72 (bs, 1H), 3.97 (s, 3H).
